Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, blueprints scattered around me. My phone buzzed again—another message from my husband. He was struggling, his words heavy with worry and fear. I knew he needed me, needed my full attention, my comfort, my presence. But my mind kept drifting to the project timeline on my screen. The client had been patient, but the team was waiting for my feedback, and I was already behind on the review. I tried to reassure my husband, typing out supportive words, but guilt gnawed at me. Was I being present enough for him? Was I letting my team down by not managing the project more closely? The weight of both expectations pressed on me, each demanding more than I felt I could give. My heart ached for my husband, but my mind raced with deadlines and responsibilities. I stared at the screen, torn, feeling the impossible pull of both worlds.
